Math.1: The Level 1 student demonstrates minimal understanding of and ability to apply the mathematics knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.
Math.2: The Level 2 student demonstrates partial understanding of and ability to apply the mathematics knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.
Math.3: The Level 3 student demonstrates adequate understanding of and ability to apply the mathematics knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.
Math.4: The Level 4 student demonstrates thorough understanding of and ability to apply the mathematics knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.

ELA.1: The Level 1 student demonstrates minimal understanding of and ability to apply the English language arts and literacy knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.
ELA.2: The Level 2 student demonstrates partial understanding of and ability to apply the English language arts and literacy knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.
ELA.3: The Level 3 student demonstrates adequate understanding of and ability to apply the English language arts and literacy knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.
ELA.4: The Level 4 student demonstrates thorough understanding of and ability to apply the English language arts and literacy knowledge and skills needed for success in college and careers, as specified in the Common Core State Standards.

psychometric_implications.Math:
Psychometric Implications:
Your overall score indicates at what level you have demonstrated progress toward college and career readiness in mathematics (Math). On your official score report, this area will describe what the {{score_name}} achievement level means, in terms of the knowledge, skills, and processes that you have demonstrated you can do, for the Grade {{grade}} Math assessment. This content will be intended to provide guidance to stakeholders on how to interpret student performance on the test. The actual text is scheduled to be written after the standard setting process in Summer 2014, and is expected to be tailored for the assessment grade and user role.
psychometric_implications.ELA:
Psychometric Implications:
Your overall score indicates at what level you have demonstrated progress toward college and career readiness in English language arts and literacy (ELA). On your official score report, this area will describe what the {{score_name}} achievement level means, in terms of the knowledge, skills, and processes that you have demonstrated you can do, for the Grade {{grade}} ELA assessment. This content will be intended to provide guidance to stakeholders on how to interpret student performance on the test. The actual text is scheduled to be written after the standard setting process in Summer 2014, and is expected to be tailored for the assessment grade and user role.

11.Math:
Policy Content:
College Content-Readiness and Admission. The College Content-Readiness Policy operates within the context of existing institutional admission policies; open-admission institutions will serve many students who do not meet the benchmark, and highly selective institutions may not admit students who score at Level 3 or 4. In addition, student course-taking decisions in HS will continue to be influenced by admission requirements of colleges and universities. For example, students at Level 4 who plan to seek admission to selective institutions will make course choices for Grade 12 that comply with the requirements of those institutions. By identifying students who are either on track or ready for credit-bearing courses, schools may be better able to advise students on college options and Grade 12 courses. Finally, institutions may choose to include SBAC scores in admission decisions.
11.ELA:
Policy Content:
College Content-Readiness and Admission. The College Content-Readiness Policy operates within the context of existing institutional admission policies; open-admission institutions will serve many students who do not meet the benchmark, and highly selective institutions may not admit students who score at Level 3 or 4. In addition, student course-taking decisions in HS will continue to be influenced by admission requirements of colleges and universities. For example, students at Level 4 who plan to seek admission to selective institutions will make course choices for Grade 12 that comply with the requirements of those institutions. By identifying students who are either on track or ready for credit-bearing courses, schools may be better able to advise students on college options and Grade 12 courses. Finally, institutions may choose to include SBAC scores in admission decisions.

Math.1:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student needs substantial support to meet college content-readiness standard. Implications: States/districts/colleges may offer supplemental programs for these students. States also may choose to retest these students near the conclusion of Grade 12. Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine placement in developmental or credit-bearing courses.
Math.2:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student needs support to meet college content- readiness standard. Implications: States/districts/colleges may implement Grade 12 transition courses or other programs for these students. States also may choose to retest these students near the conclusion of Grade 12 (scoring will occur within two weeks, allowing opportunity for colleges to use scores the following fall). Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine placement in developmental or credit- bearing courses.
Math.3:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student is exempt from developmental course work, contingent on evidence of continued learning in Grade 12. Implications: Within each state, higher education and K–12 officials determine appropriate evidence of continued learning (such as test scores or course grades). For students who demonstrate evidence of continued learning in Grade 12, colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine student placement in advanced courses beyond an initial entry-level course. Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine placement in developmental or credit-bearing courses for students who fail to demonstrate sufficient evidence of continued learning in Grade 12.
Math.4:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student is exempt from developmental course work. Implications: States/districts/colleges may offer advanced courses (such as AP, IB, or dual enrollment) for these students. Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, placement test scores, writing samples, etc.) to determine student placement in advanced courses beyond an initial entry-level course.

ELA.1:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student needs substantial support to meet college content-readiness standard. Implications: States/districts/colleges may offer supplemental programs for these students. States also may choose to retest these students near the conclusion of Grade 12. Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine placement in developmental or credit-bearing courses.
ELA.2:

Implications: States/districts/colleges may implement Grade 12 transition courses or other programs for these students. States also may choose to retest these students near the conclusion of Grade 12 (scoring will occur within two weeks, allowing opportunity for colleges to use scores the following fall). Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine placement in developmental or credit- bearing courses.
ELA.3:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student is exempt from developmental course work, contingent on evidence of continued learning in Grade 12. Implications: Within each state, higher education and K–12 officials determine appropriate evidence of continued learning (such as test scores or course grades). For students who demonstrate evidence of continued learning in Grade 12, colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine student placement in advanced courses beyond an initial entry-level course. Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, portfolios, placement test scores, etc.) to determine placement in developmental or credit-bearing courses for students who fail to demonstrate sufficient evidence of continued learning in Grade 12.
ELA.4:
Policy Content:
College Content Readiness: Student is exempt from developmental course work. Implications: States/districts/colleges may offer advanced courses (such as AP, IB, or dual enrollment) for these students. Colleges may evaluate additional data (courses completed, grades, placement test scores, writing samples, etc.) to determine student placement in advanced courses beyond an initial entry-level course.

Math.1: Students can explain and apply mathematical concepts and carry out mathematical procedures with precision and fluency.
Math.2: Students can solve a range of complex, well-posed problems in pure and applied mathematics, making productive use of knowledge and problem solving strategies. Students can analyze complex, real-world scenarios and can construct and use mathematical models to interpret and solve problems.
Math.3: Students can clearly and precisely construct viable arguments to support their own reasoning and to critique the reasoning of others.

ELA.1: Students can read closely and analytically to comprehend a range of increasingly complex literary and informational texts.
ELA.2: Students can produce effective and well-grounded writing for a range of purposes and audiences.
ELA.3: Students can employ effective speaking and listening skills for a range of purposes and audiences.
ELA.4: Students can engage in research and inquiry to investigate topics and to analyze, integrate, and present information.
